awd_titl_txt: Research in Noncommutative Algebra:  Hopf Algebra Actions on Noetherian Artin-Schelter  Regular Algebras and Noncommutative McKay Correspondence
awd_abstract_narration:
Invariants such as dimensions and symmetries are useful tools in mathematics and other disciplines. Understanding links between different invariants is a demanding task in modern mathematics. This research project is to study noncommutative algebras (mathematical structures in which xy does not necessarily equal yx) by using algebraic, combinatorial, geometric, and other invariants, and to build a bridge between the subject of noncommutative algebra and other active research areas.  The PI will investigate the structure of several important families of algebras and work on central questions in the subject. Since noncommutative algebras have been used extensively, this project will deepen the understanding of other mathematical areas including noncommutative algebraic geometry, commutative algebra and mathematical physics.

A central theme of the proposal is the noncommutative McKay correspondence, a concept motivated by the classical McKay correspondence that has recently been extended to several new areas. Specific topics include noncommutative quotient singularities of Hopf algebra actions on Artin-Schelter regular algebras; skew Calabi-Yau property and the Nakayama automorphism of Artin-Schelter Gorenstein algebras; and the noncommutative discriminant of algebras which are module-finite over their center. The PI has introduced a number of invariants with fruitful applications in the study of automorphism groups and locally nilpotent derivations of noncommutative algebras, as well as the noncommutative Zariski cancellation problem. The PI will continue to search for distinct invariants of noncommutative algebras, to develop foundations for new research directions, and to work on central open questions in the field. The noncommutative McKay correspondence is one essential guideline for the interplay between noncommutative algebra, Hopf algebra and theory of quantum groups, noncommutative invariant theory, and noncommutative algebraic geometry.

por.por_cntn:
This research project concerns noncommutative algebras that arise from category theory, noncommutative algebraic geometry, and representation theory. One main program is the McKay correspondence in the noncommutative setting. As in the classical case, the McKay correspondence relates different areas such as algebra, geometry, combinatorics, and mathematical physics. A central theme is to investigate invariants that capture distinguished features of mathematical objects. These invariants play an essential and effective role in understanding complicated objects in mathematics, physics and other disciplines.


For the intellectual merit, the PI has been working on Hopf algebra actions on Artin-Schelter regular algebras and studying induced quotient singularities and the associated McKay correspondence. He introduced several new methods to develop noncommutative versions of Auslander's isomorphism theorem, equivalences of categories encoding McKay quiver, Auslander quiver, and Gabriel quiver, and noncommutative resolutions for algebras that do not satisfy a polynomial identity. In addition, the PI has been working on other topics: automorphism and Zariski cancellation problems,operad theory, noncommutative discriminant, Frobenius-Perron dimension of abelian and triangulated categories, homological regularities such as Castelnuovo-Mumford regularity, Tor-regularity, Ext-regularity, and Artin-Schelter regularity for connected graded algebras. During the award period, the PI together with his coauthors had finished more than 20 research papers and answered a few open questions about the Hilbert series of symmetric operads. The PI together with his co-organizers had organized several conferences, including a week-long international conference in Seattle from June 20-24, 2022. 


For broader impacts, this project will have applications in physics and other disciplines in a long run. Representation theory of noncommutative algebras and categorical analogues of such have frequently been used in computer science and statistics. It is expected to have more connections between noncommutative algebra (and category theory) and computer science as well as statistics. Many graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and visiting researchers have been benefited from our research activities. This project also provides opportunities for undergraduate students who want to explore advanced mathematics research. This award partly supported the Washington Directed Reading Program for undergraduate students at the University of Washington.
